awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Towards Secure Networked Cyber-Physical Systems: A Theoretic Framework with Bounded Rationality
awd_abstract_narration:
Securing critical networked cyber-physical systems (NCPSs) such as the power grid or transportation systems has emerged as a major national and global priority. The networked nature of such systems renders them vulnerable to a range of attacks both in cyber and physical domains as corroborated by recent threats such as the Stuxnet worm. Developing security mechanisms for such NCPSs significantly differs from traditional networked systems due to interdependence between cyber and physical subsystems (with attacks originating from either subsystem), possible cooperation between attackers or defenders, and the presence of human decision makers in the loop. The main goal of this research is to develop the necessary science and engineering tools for designing NCPS security solutions that are applicable to a broad range of application domains. 

This project will develop a multidisciplinary framework that weaves together principles from cybersecurity, control theory, networking and criminology. The framework will include novel security mechanisms for NCPSs founded on solid control-theoretic and related notions, analytical tools that allow incorporation of bounded human rationality in NCPS security, and experiments with real-world attack scenarios. A newly built cross-institutional NCPS simulator will be used to evaluate the proposed mechanisms in realistic environments. This research transcends specific cyber-physical systems domains and provides the necessary tools to building secure and trustworthy NCPSs. The broader impacts include a new infrastructure for NCPS research and education, training of students, new courses, and outreach events focused on under-represented student groups.

por.por_cntn:
During the period of this award, FIU, Virginia Tech, and Temple Universities have developed solutions that help to secure critical networked cyber-physical systems (NCPSs) such as the power grid, or transportation systems has emerged as a major national and global priority. The networked nature of such systems renders them vulnerable to a range of attacks both in cyber and physical domains as corroborated by recent threats such as the Stuxnet worm. Developing security mechanisms for such NCPSs significantly differs from traditional networked systems due to interdependence between cyber and physical subsystems (with attacks originating from either subsystem), possible cooperation between attackers or defenders, and the presence of human decision-makers in the loop.

A stochastic game-theoretic approach was proposed to analyze the optimal strategies that a critical networked cyber-physical system can adopt to protect the system against coordinated attacks. First, for a power grid, an optimal load shedding technique is devised to quantify the physical impacts of coordinated attacks. Taking these quantified impacts as input parameters, the interactions between a malicious attacker and the defender are modeled using a resource allocation stochastic game. The game was shown to admit a Nash equilibrium, and a novel learning algorithm is introduced to enable the two players to reach their equilibrium strategies while maximizing their respective minimum rewards in a sequence of stages. The convergence of the proposed algorithm to a Nash equilibrium point is proved, and its properties are studied. Simulation results of the stochastic game model on a power system network, which I part of an NCPS in contrast to static games, show that different defense resources owned lead to different defense strategies.

In this project, an attempt to study the behavior of a remotely connected NCPS environment under coordinated, sequential attacks on communication and cyber-physical levels were made. In order to demonstrate the feasibility of Message Integrity Attack (MIA), Packet Drop Attack (PDA), and Delay Attack (DA)on NCPS, two identical CPS hardware-based testbeds at FIU in Miami and TU in Philadelphia were considered. The results illustrated the plausibility and widespread effects of cascading failures in the form of four sequential events when subject to communication attacks. The study concluded that the components of NCPSs could be protected with consistent packet sampling and analysis, and by setting specific threshold values for throughput and delay to detect attacks.

In order to achieve more efficient and cost-effective communication between NCPSs, a spectrum sharing based AMI using LTE and WiFi was investigated. In the proposed method, the WiFi was used in smart meters for transferring data to data collector (also termed as Access point (AP)). After collecting data from a group of meters, AP transfers the data to MDMS using the LTE. The simulation performance shows a harmonious neighborhood spectrum sharing between LTE and WiFi. With the increase of the LTE duty cycle, the throughput, energy efficiency, and SINR of LTE are improved along with the degradation of those of WIFI. The lower duty cycle of LTE transmission can be selected for urban and suburban areas where the density of smart meters is high, and meters need more access to WiFi. On the other hand, the higher duty of LTE transmission can be selected for rural areas where the density of smart meter is low. The CBRS band has a large amount of free, underutilized, and clean spectrum for the wireless network. So, network consists of coexisting LTE and WiFi in CBRS band can be a viable communication solution for effective communication between NCPSs

The research presented new content, ideas, thoughts, and case studies in education programs at FIU and developed to improve CPS based programs. A new Masters program in Energy Cyber Security at FIU ECE department benefitted from the studies and outcome of this product during its execution period. The research established great cooperation and contact between the PI and the Co-PIs; it encouraged them to do new research activities and collaborative efforts. This research led to an efficient connection and collaboration between Virginia Tech and the Co-PIs at Temple University as well.

Technologies relating to this effort have been significantly improved in the area of communication, cybersecurity, data analysis, game theory, network science, optimization, and power systems.

12 conferences, 6 Journals, and 1 submitted book chapter have emanated from these efforts with a high volume of new information added to literature in the field of security of networked cyber-physical systems.
